H0.text: Increasing the current in the circuit is the change a hardware designer would make to solve the problem of the wiring in a circuit releasing enough heat to make the circuit dangerously hot.

H1.text: Placing rubber insulation on wires in the circuit is the change that best solves the problem of the wiring releasing enough heat to make the circuit dangerously hot.

H2.text: Reversing the direction of current flow in the circuit is the best change to address the hardware designer’s finding that the wiring is releasing enough heat to make the circuit dangerously hot.

H3.text: Using circuit wires with a lower resistance is the change that would best solve the problem of wiring in a circuit releasing enough heat to make the circuit dangerously hot.

A4.text: Joule's first law (also just Joule's law), also known in countries of the former USSR as the Joule–Lenz law, states that the power of heating generated by an electrical conductor equals the product of its resistance and the square of the current.

A5.text: Joule heating does not occur in superconducting materials, as these materials have zero electrical resistance in the superconducting state.
